article.text: Tuesday 10 April 2012 3:47PM BST 10 Apr 2012 Foreign Secretary William Hague said if the peace plan failed, Britain "will begin the process of seeking the referral by the Security Council of the situation in Syria to the International Criminal Court". Troops loyal to President Bashar al-Assad bombarded the Bayada and Khalidiya districts of the city of Homs, killing at least 26 people, The central city of Hama was also shelled on Tuesday morning, activists said. "We have at least 20 martyrs and 70 wounded, most of them women and children," one activist who identified himself as Abu Yasser told Under Annan's peace plan Mr Assad was to stop attacking protest hubs on Tuesday ahead of a ceasefire on Thursday. Opposition forces are expected to Despite Mr Assad's promise to accept the ceasefire deadline violence has surged in opposition areas since April 5, when the UN formally backed Mr Factbox: the growing Syrian refugee crisis Syrian army shell Hama on eve of ceasefire Syria: regime shells towns despite ceasefire deadline On Monday at least 105 people were killed in the attacks, taking the death toll to nearly 300 over the past three days, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. A spokeswoman for the Syrian National Council said the pro-government troops have defied the April 10 ceasefire agreement. SNC spokeswoman Bassma Kodmani told reporters in Geneva on Tuesday that regime forces intensified their onslaught in opposition areas, using heavy weapons including anti-aircraft guns against civilians. The rebel Free Syrian Army said it will ceasefire only if Mr Assad removes his forces and stops attacking opposition forces. But Walid Muallem, Syria's foreign minister, told reporters in Moscow after a meeting with his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov that Damascus had already begun implementing Mr Annan's peace plan. "I told my Russian colleague of the steps Syria is taking to show its goodwill for the implementation of the Annan plan. We have already withdrawn military units from different Syrian provinces," Mr Muallem said. However, Russia's Foreign Minister made it very clear that Syria must be more "decisive" in fulfilling the peace plan. "We believe their actions could have been more active, more decisive when it comes to the implementation of the plan," Mr Lavrov told the joint news conference with Muallem.
